metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

generationDetails.description: Each lesson generated as many valid questions as possible

questions.question: Which layer of the Earth forms the planet’s surface and is the thinnest of all the layers?

answers.content: Crust
answers.explanation: The crust is the thin, outermost layer on which we live.

answers.content: Mantle
answers.explanation: The mantle lies below the crust and is much thicker.

answers.content: Outer core
answers.explanation: The outer core is a liquid metal layer deep inside Earth.

answers.content: Inner core
answers.explanation: The inner core is the solid metal centre of Earth.

questions.question: Place the following list in the correct order from the Earth’s centre outward.

answers.content: Inner core, outer core, mantle, crust
answers.explanation: This sequence goes from the deepest to the surface.

answers.content: Outer core, inner core, mantle, crust
answers.explanation: The inner core is deeper than the outer core.

answers.content: Mantle, crust, inner core, outer core
answers.explanation: The crust is on top, not in the middle.

answers.content: Crust, mantle, inner core, outer core
answers.explanation: The outer core surrounds the inner core, not vice-versa.

questions.question: Despite temperatures as hot as the surface of the Sun, the inner core remains solid. Explain why.

answers.content: Immense pressure from the overlying layers keeps the iron–nickel inner core in a solid state even at very high temperatures.

questions.question: Draw, label and colour a cross-section of the Earth showing the crust, mantle, outer core and inner core. Include one annotated fact about the temperature or composition of EACH layer.

answers.content: Student supplies annotated diagram with four labelled layers and accurate fact for each.
answers.explanation: Full marks awarded for correct labels, colours and facts.

questions.question: Which two metallic elements make up most of Earth’s core?

answers.content: Iron and nickel
answers.explanation: Both the outer and inner cores are largely molten or solid iron and nickel.

answers.content: Iron and aluminium
answers.explanation: Aluminium is abundant in the crust, not the core.

answers.content: Nickel and copper
answers.explanation: Copper is not a dominant element in the core.

answers.content: Magnesium and silicon
answers.explanation: These are more common in the mantle.

questions.question: Which layer is described as semi-solid rock that flows very slowly and drives plate movement?

answers.content: Mantle
answers.explanation: Slow convection currents in the mantle move tectonic plates.

answers.content: Crust
answers.explanation: The crust is rigid and brittle.

answers.content: Outer core
answers.explanation: The outer core is liquid metal.

answers.content: Inner core
answers.explanation: The inner core is solid metal.

questions.question: Approximately how thick is Earth’s continental crust? (Accept answers in kilometres.)

answers.content: About 30–70 km (any specific value within this range).

questions.question: The slow, heat-driven circulation in the mantle that can lead to volcanic eruptions is called:

answers.content: Convection
answers.explanation: Heat causes mantle material to rise and sink in convection currents.

answers.content: Radiation
answers.explanation: Radiation is energy transfer through waves, not fluid movement.

answers.content: Conduction
answers.explanation: Conduction is direct heat transfer between touching solids.

answers.content: Erosion
answers.explanation: Erosion wears away surfaces; it is not a mantle process.

questions.question: State one difference between the crust beneath continents and the crust beneath oceans.

answers.content: Continental crust is generally thicker and composed mainly of granite, whereas oceanic crust is thinner and mainly basalt.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the outer core?

answers.content: A hot liquid layer of iron and nickel that surrounds the inner core
answers.explanation: The outer core is molten metal.

answers.content: A rigid shell of solid rock broken into plates
answers.explanation: That describes the lithospheric part of the crust.

answers.content: A semi-solid layer that slowly flows
answers.explanation: That describes the mantle, not the outer core.

answers.content: A thin layer of soil and sediment covering continents
answers.explanation: That is part of the uppermost crust, not the outer core.

questions.question: What is the main cause of most earthquakes on Earth?

answers.content: The sudden release of built-up tension when tectonic plates get stuck and then move
answers.explanation: Earthquakes occur when stress along faults or plate boundaries is suddenly released, causing the ground to shake.

answers.content: Gradual sinking of the Earth’s crust
The Moon’s gravity pulling on the continents
Large storms in the atmosphere

questions.question: In the Mars-bar model, which part of the chocolate bar represents Earth’s crust?

answers.content: The thin chocolate coating on the outside
answers.explanation: The brittle chocolate layer mimics Earth’s rigid crust that can crack and buckle.

answers.content: The soft caramel layer
The nougat centre
The wrapper

questions.question: Why does Australia experience relatively few strong earthquakes compared with countries like Japan?

answers.content: Australia lies in the centre of a tectonic plate, away from most plate boundaries
answers.explanation: Most large earthquakes occur at plate boundaries; Australia is located far from these zones.

answers.content: Australia is located on the equator
Australia’s crust is thicker than other continents
Australia’s climate is too dry for earthquakes to occur

questions.question:
Complete the causal sentence using the conjunction ‘so’ to explain one effect of the Noto Peninsula earthquake.

The earthquake struck, so _________________________.

answers.content: the land rose up and changed the shape of the coastline.
answers.explanation: Any scientifically correct effect that uses ‘so’ to link cause and effect earns full marks, e.g. “…so buildings collapsed and roads cracked.”

questions.question: When the epicentre of an earthquake is under the ocean, what secondary hazard can it generate (shown as purple flashes in the video)?

answers.content: A tsunami
answers.explanation: Under-sea earthquakes can displace huge volumes of water, creating a series of powerful waves called a tsunami.

answers.content: A hurricane
A drought
A sandstorm

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram that models how two tectonic plates collide using a cut-in-half Mars bar. Include labels for ‘tectonic plate’, ‘crust folds/cracks’ and an arrow showing the direction of movement.

answers.content: Teacher-scored
answers.explanation: Award up to 2 marks: 1 mark for a clear diagram of two Mars-bar halves being pushed together with arrows, 1 mark for accurate labels (e.g., crust, plate, folds/cracks).

questions.question: During a volcanic eruption, what is the correct scientific term for the liquid rock that flows out of the volcano and over the ground?

answers.content: Lava
answers.explanation: Lava is molten rock that has reached Earth’s surface.

answers.content: Magma
answers.explanation: Magma is molten rock while it is still beneath Earth’s surface.

answers.content: Ash
answers.explanation: Ash is the fine particulate material blasted into the air during an eruption.

answers.content: Sediment
answers.explanation: Sediment is weathered or eroded material, not molten rock.

questions.question: Which statement BEST describes a constructive effect of volcanic eruptions on Earth’s surface?

answers.content: Eruptions bury cities under ash, making them uninhabitable.
answers.explanation: This is a destructive effect.

answers.content: Volcanic gases block sunlight and cool the climate.
answers.explanation: This is generally considered a negative global impact.

answers.content: Lava flows break down into fertile soils that support rich plant growth.
answers.explanation: Weathered lava produces mineral-rich, fertile soils that benefit agriculture.

answers.content: Pyroclastic flows destroy forests and farmland.
answers.explanation: This is a destructive effect.

questions.question: In the model eruption activity, name ONE immediate change to the landscape you observed AND describe ONE knock-on effect that could follow. Use a causal connective such as "so", "therefore" or "because" in your answer.

answers.content: Immediate change: lava covered the sand landscape. Knock-on effect: plants and animals would be unable to live there because the hot lava destroys their habitat.
answers.explanation: Any reasonable pair that links a landscape change to a logical consequence earns full marks.

questions.question: What is the name of the underground reservoir where molten rock collects before it rises through a volcano?

answers.content: Mantle plume
answers.explanation: A mantle plume is a column of hot rock, not a reservoir.

answers.content: Magma chamber
answers.explanation: A magma chamber stores molten rock beneath the volcano.

answers.content: Vent
answers.explanation: A vent is the passage the magma travels through.

answers.content: Crater lake
answers.explanation: A crater lake forms in an extinct or dormant volcano’s crater, not beneath the surface.

questions.question: Archaeologists uncovered many artefacts when Pompeii was rediscovered. Give TWO different artefacts and explain what each one taught scientists about daily life in ancient Pompeii.

answers.content: Example answer: Loaves of bread found in ovens showed what kinds of food Romans ate, and public bath remains revealed how Romans kept clean and socialised.
answers.explanation: Accept any two valid artefact-information pairs such as bread/ diet, gladiator school/ entertainment, theatres/ leisure, baths/ hygiene, shops/ commerce.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram that shows a volcano during an eruption and at least TWO ways the surrounding landscape is changed (e.g., lava flow covering land, ash cloud settling on buildings). Your labels must include the terms "lava" and a causal connective explaining one knock-on effect.

answers.content:
Teacher-marked drawing; rubric: 
• Volcano and lava flow clearly drawn (1 mark) 
• Two landscape changes shown (1 mark) 
• Correct labels including the word "lava" (1 mark) 
• One sentence with a causal connective explaining a knock-on effect (1 mark)
answers.explanation: Assess drawings against rubric.

questions.question: Which statement BEST defines weathering?

answers.content: The process that breaks rocks into smaller pieces on Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: Weathering refers specifically to the breakdown of rock in-situ.

answers.content: The movement of broken rock from one place to another.
answers.explanation: That is erosion, not weathering.

answers.content: Molten rock cooling to form new igneous rocks.
answers.explanation: This is solidification of magma, not weathering.

answers.content: Plants growing in nutrient-rich soil.
answers.explanation: Plant growth can cause weathering, but this option does not define it.

questions.question: Which THREE of the following are agents of weathering studied in this lesson?

answers.content: Wind
Moving water
Plants
Gravity
answers.explanation: Gravity influences erosion more than weathering.

answers.content: Lightning
answers.explanation: Lightning can fracture rock but was not examined in this lesson.

questions.question: In the sugar-cube investigation, what variable MOST DIRECTLY caused the cubes to weather?

answers.content: Shaking, which made the cubes collide with each other.
answers.explanation: The collisions imitate rock fragments bumping together in nature.

answers.content: The colour of the paper underneath.
answers.explanation: Paper colour did not affect weathering.

answers.content: The amount of sunlight hitting the jar.
answers.explanation: Sunlight was not manipulated in the investigation.

answers.content: The temperature of the room.
answers.explanation: Room temperature remained constant and was not the key factor.

questions.question: Why do sharp rocks on a seashore gradually become smooth pebbles?

answers.content: Sand and other particles in waves grind against them repeatedly.
answers.explanation: Moving water and abrasive particles round off edges over time.

answers.content: Heat from the Sun melts the edges of the rocks.
answers.explanation: The temperatures are not high enough to melt rock.

answers.content: Plants grow on every rock surface and make it smoother.
answers.explanation: Plant roots can crack rock but do not smooth it uniformly.

answers.content: Earth’s gravity pulls the rocks downward, flattening them.
answers.explanation: Gravity alone does not smooth rock surfaces.

questions.question: Which causal connective is NOT used in the model paragraph about water weathering rocks?

answers.content: Because
answers.explanation: The paragraph uses 'due to', 'so', and 'as a result' but not 'because'.

answers.content: Due to
answers.explanation: This connective appears in the topic sentence.

answers.content: So
answers.explanation: 'So' is used to link cause and effect.

answers.content: As a result
answers.explanation: 'As a result' appears in the concluding sentence.

questions.question: Which pair of landforms was recommended for comparison in the Venn diagram activity?

answers.content: Karlu Karlu (Devils Marbles) and Wave Rock
The Three Sisters and Giant’s Causeway
answers.explanation: These were mentioned elsewhere but not the focus of the Venn diagram.

answers.content: Uluru and Mount Kosciuszko
answers.explanation: These landforms were not part of the activity.

answers.content: Grand Canyon and Blue Mountains
answers.explanation: Not referenced in the lesson instructions.

questions.question: Explain ONE way that plant roots contribute to the weathering of rocks.

answers.content: Plant roots grow into small cracks in rock. As the roots thicken they push the crack wider, breaking the rock into smaller pieces over time.
answers.explanation: Roots exert pressure that physically splits rock apart.

questions.question: Describe the MAIN difference between weathering and erosion.

answers.content: Weathering is the breakdown of rock in the place where it is found, while erosion is the transport of the broken pieces to a new location by wind, water, ice or gravity.
answers.explanation: This distinction was emphasised in the teacher notes.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple flow chart that shows how moving water weathers a rock from a sharp edge to a smooth pebble (include at least three steps).

answers.content: Model answer includes sequential sketches: 1) Sharp rock in river; 2) Particles in water hit rock, chipping edges; 3) Repeated impacts round the rock into a smooth pebble. Arrows and causal labels such as 'abrasion' are present.
answers.explanation: Any drawing that correctly sequences the process with labels earns full marks.

questions.question: A student claimed, "Weathering always happens quickly if you can see it in an experiment." How would you respond based on the sugar-cube model?

answers.content: The experiment speeds up the process; in nature, the same changes take many years.
answers.explanation: Shaking applies continuous force, unlike slow natural forces.

answers.content: Weathering never happens in nature at all.
Weathering only happens to sugar, not to real rock.
Natural weathering happens at exactly the same speed as in the jar.

questions.question: What is erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces.
answers.explanation: Breaking rocks is weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand to another place.
answers.explanation: Erosion transports the weathered material to a new location.

answers.content: The cooling of molten rock.
answers.explanation: Cooling molten rock forms igneous rocks and is unrelated to erosion.

answers.content: The process of plants growing roots in soil.
answers.explanation: Root growth is biological activity and not erosion.

questions.question: In the class investigation, which variable was deliberately changed to test its effect on erosion?

answers.content: Amount of water poured into each tray.
answers.explanation: The amount of water remained the same to keep the test fair.

answers.content: Type of sand used in the trays.
answers.explanation: The same damp sand was used in every trial.

answers.content: Slope of the tray (flat, gentle, steep).
answers.explanation: Only the slope was changed to investigate its impact on erosion.

answers.content: Length of the 'river' drawn in the sand.
answers.explanation: The same river length was used in each tray.

questions.question: Why did the tray with the steepest slope show the greatest amount of erosion?

answers.content: Steeper slopes reduce the water’s force, allowing more deposition.
answers.explanation: Steeper slopes actually increase the water’s force.

answers.content: Water travels faster down a steeper slope, increasing its kinetic energy and erosive force.
answers.explanation: Greater speed means greater force, so more sediment is carried away.

answers.content: The sand in the steep tray was drier.
answers.explanation: All trays used the same damp sand.

answers.content: Gravity is weaker on steeper slopes.
answers.explanation: Gravity acts the same; the slope angle changes how gravity accelerates water.

questions.question: Which pair of natural forces are highlighted in the lesson as major causes of erosion?

answers.content: Wind and water.
answers.explanation: Wind and moving water both transport weathered material, causing erosion.

answers.content: Earthquakes and volcanoes.
answers.explanation: These cause sudden landform changes but are not the focus of this erosion lesson.

answers.content: Sunlight and gravity.
answers.explanation: Gravity assists erosion, but sunlight is not a direct erosive force.

answers.content: Magnetism and electricity.
answers.explanation: These forces are unrelated to erosion of Earth’s surface.

questions.question: Explain how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Dreaming stories, such as the tale of Super Snake, contribute to our understanding of landform formation.

answers.content: Dreaming stories offer cultural explanations of how landscapes were created, helping students connect spiritual, historical and environmental perspectives with scientific ideas about processes like weathering and erosion.

questions.question: State the conclusion you would write to answer the scientific question: "Does the force of water cause more erosion when it flows down a steeper slope?"

answers.content: Yes. Water flowing down a steeper slope has greater speed and force, which transports more sand, resulting in increased erosion compared with gentle or flat slopes.
